ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: There were issues with conduct and paying attention in class. Classmates could have been more respectful but I think it was a reflection on issues with the way the information is delivered. If instruction was more participatory (moving away from a lecture format into more discussion) or interactive (recordings of shows or bringing artists in to perform) the class would be more engaging and successful. This is not a critique on the teacher at all who I believe to be a kind, intelligent, competent and wonderful human and educator. The format of the class was the difficulty.
It would have been better if the the reading lined up with the classes we had discussion.
I retained more information in the discussions. The Lecture did help to put names to faces and organize my thoughts when it was time to take the exam.

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: Although lectures are well-conceived there is not a good balance between lecture/class discussion. Discussion section does not provide enough time to discuss both readings and all the material/concepts covered in class.
More discussion based activity would have increased engagement.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: I did not feel that the essay this semester furthered my learning about a particular time period or style. It seemed like in exercise in description and observation but not really related to history or the point of the class
The essay was too open. I felt unsure what to write about or argue.
I enjoyed the essay assignment.
I liked the prompt for the essay in 6B it gave us lots of freedom to pick a play that interested us.

I thought the paper were a good opportunity to examine a text more closely than previously. I certainly wished that for a drama history course we would actually watch and examine drama. In replacement of a couple of readings, a few short reports on a piece of drama would be an effective way of discussing theatrical conventions.

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: it would have been better if reading was relevant to the discussion that was supposed to happen that week.
The workload was too overwhelming to keep up with in conjunction with production work and other coursework.

narratives.question_text: How did the supplementary materials (files, videos, recordings, etc.) for the course enhance your experience of it?
comments: The power points are useful as a quick reference when studying but do not contain all the information discussed in class

It was helpful to have the power points to prepare for the test. Then I realized I didn't have to always pay attention in class because the gist of the classes were on the power points. I would have liked more supplementary material of actual performances or interviews with artists.
The powerpoints were not really helpful. Too many words with no real information.
We didnt have that many supplementary materials to work from aside from assigned text.

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: Unfortunately it was difficult to retain all of the info. So much was covered I did not develop a deep understanding of specific eras or concepts.

Much of the content was very interesting to me and I am thankful to know it as I continue to create artistic work that is knowledgable and in dialogue with the western cannon past and present. I know that most of the details of dates and names will leave my memory in the next month, but I will still retain the patterns and the longer narrative of how theatre has changed over time. Not remembering the names and dates doesn't bother me because I know I can always look it up online, which is the norm nowadays. That being said, because we live in a society that can get information from searching it online, having to memorize a lot of dates and names felt frustrating and not the most helpful use of my time. I say this knowing that I can because my department doesn't ask me to know all these information by heart. I think an open notes final would help alleviate stress to memorize by rote. People would be able to focus more on trends and patterns and have critical discussion about the history of theatre.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: yes if they are interested in theatre history.
It a good overview of theater history and the information itself is interesting. However, it is often presented in a dull memorized fashion.
no

I would recommend auditing the course. I think listening to the lectures, doing the readings without the pressure of the midterm/final would be fun. However, I would not recommend officially taking the course if it meant participating in the midterm/final. It feels we are mostly graded on our ability to memorize an immense amount of info that may or may not actually feel relevant to us. I did not retain much of what I studied.
eh, not particularly.

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: There was no grading rubric given on the syllabus.

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: Paul is a master at what he does. He has an impeccably hard job and does it with the utmost grace.
Paul is an expert! He knows his stuff! His lectures are very well written and in-depth.

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: While there was a lot of information in the lectures it was hard to synthesis and the power-points were not really helpful in studying/further learning.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to consider diverse points of view.
comments: Your questions sections at the end of class always opened the doors to anyone's point of view
Paul would often respond to student questions with added research embedded into future lectures. I appreciated his flexibility and willingness to do so. This is dedication!

narratives.question_text: The instructor was willing to answer pertinent questions.
comments: You always to people's questions into consideration as if you did not know the answer on the spot, it was always looked into and brought up in the following class
When we had time, Paul always answered questions and gave further context. He is very knowledgable and approachable.

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: I think the basic criteria is explained - but the TA's all grade in different ways. I am not sure if they share a common rubric. For instance, I had Ilinca in the fall semester and did not understand her system (she was also a harsh grader), whereas Sam was much clearer in how she grades.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: I did not reach out to you so I can not speak to this question truly but it seemed like most issues or question were addressed through the TAs
Paul is great.

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: You seem to care about the students outside of the classroom but in class you always seem a distant and removed. Perhaps if I reached out and got to know you better I would feel differently.

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: I missed one class and discussion session during load-in for Rep 3. It was the first Thursday class of the semester. I was one of the ADTs and could not step away from the production at that time.
The majority.
All.
all
None. I tested out at the beginning of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: I did not do one of the responses and there were several occasions were I did not read the plays very closely. It was more of a skim than an in depth read do to the time constraints of my production assignments

No, the required work was a hassle and not in the department I came to study for. I would have been more interested in the class if it was based on required attendance and less on weekly assignments that I had no interest in. I do like learning about theatre history, I enjoyed the lectures, but did not particularly enjoy the discussion or feel like I gained much from the essays or weekly prompts.

Things that work: - Paul creates really interesting, organized, in-depth lectures. I am grateful that I saved most of the PowerPoints so I always can return to this material in future. - I appreciate the gargantuan effort and intellect it requires to teach the immense volume of information covered in the course. Things that could be improved upon: - The format and expectations of the class are difficult for non-academic theatre students who best thrive by putting things into practice (rather than memorizing volumes of information for tests.) - Dropping one of the tests in favor of an interactive project - like actors performing a melodrama, or playwrights writing in a particular genre, design students designing for a specific era would be a better use of our skills. And then we would at least retrain in-depth knowledge on at least one area of study. - Rethinking what this course can and should accomplish for students. - Opening up the canon to consider more women artists, artists of color.

narratives.question_text: How would you rate the overall usefulness of discussion sections for this class?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Was enough time devoted to discussion sections?
comments: I wish there was more.

narratives.question_text: Did you attend all the discussions?
comments: As said above, I missed the first discussion session do to my obligations to Rep 3. Otherwise I attended all sessions and both review session for the midterm and final
Almost all.
Yes
Yes
